amazing stuff so every one of those pins has got two wires running through it and
they were actually made by hand mostly by women with microscopes passing these
wires through these uh these pins and the cost of magnetic core memory in the
early days was about one dollar per bit so a byte cost you eight dollars and so
it was important to use as few bytes as possible and so the standard date type
in Cobalt which was the language of the time was a pick nine of six that's uh a
number with six digits six bytes because that
saved sixteen dollars in memory space and if you've got a whole sort of day's

thing that we have a using statement so you can put that variable into a using
block and then when that block finishes it will be disposed and one of the key
things that you always have to do this with is database connection objects because they're really expensive and
there is a limited number of them and they use a lot of memory and this application was talking to an Oracle
database and there were about 20 places where they were creating an oracle DB
connection and in none of them were they disposing of that connection when they were finished with it so this
application was leaking enormous amounts of memory tying up all the Oracle database space connections and then
crashing that was the point at which these connections got disposed so I added using statements to these 20
places and it fixed it and then I went through and it's like okay that was 30

recursion um Fibonacci sequences and all this sort of stuff so people oh you should use
recursion and you should use languages that have tail call optimization to handle your recursion because if you do
it in a language that doesn't have that you will get a stack Overflow exception you call a method that calls itself and
then it calls itself again and then it calls itself again every time it does one of those calls it puts the parameters on the stack and eventually
the stack fills up and your program can literally do nothing at that point except crash
and so this is why generally we have four loops and while loops and four
reach loops and do while loops and that sort of thing because tail call optimization is hard but um so this is
uh some code um that uh is compiled with the Net Framework
the 32-bit version the 64-bit version of the.net framework the jit does have tail
call optimization but if you compile it with the 32-bit version the x86 version
it will just Chuck out this code which will eventually get a stack Overflow if you start it with a from that's big
enough if you compile it with x64 it does tail call optimization
and you can see down at l0014 it's doing a jump to l007
so it turns out that a tail call optimization is just to go to
